moves.1. d4 d5 2. Bf4 Nf6 3. Nf3 Nc6 4. Nbd2 h: All normal stuff. Just note: if I don't play this move now, in the near future Nb5 by black can annoy me a lot, given the threats on c7 and d6. True, white can defend with Qa5+, forcing the N back, but after e6 or Qd7 this doesn't work anymore.
moves.6... e6 7. g4 Bh7: Black, normally retreats on g6, making Ne5 a good move. Even better if I play something like Qa4 first, pinning the Nc6. But now, I wanted to experiment.
moves.8. g5: ?! If Nh5, Be3. It blocks my central pawn, but I have Bh2, followed by a tempo when moving the e pawn.
moves.8... hxg5 9. Bxg5: This B can't be harassed anymore by h6. I thought on Nxg5, but black's lsb can move away, and it seemed a bad idea to me. One of the central features of this opening is N's control on e5.
moves.9... Be7 10. h4: "cementing" the B. But all this in unexplored territory for me, and I'm not sure it will work.
moves.10... Ne4 11. Rg1: This is the central idea. My h pawn will go to g5, so his R won't threat it.
moves.11... Bxg5 12. Nxg5 Nxg5: Here I played too quickly hxN, Maybe Rxg5 was better, with tempo on g7.
moves.13. hxg5 Bg6 14. f4: I am aware my kingside is completely exposed, but I thought the pawn chain was strong enough to prevent black's incursions. I was wrong.
moves.14... Qd6 15. e3 O-O-O: Ok, so I have a very strong pawn chain, but nothing more, and his lsb is really annoying. Under control, but still annoying. A possible attack plan was b4, but hey, I am very underdeveloped.
moves.16. Nb3: It looks as a bad move, but my N has a nice outpost in c5, and if b6, Ba6+ looks interesting. Moreover, I can now play Bd3 so to exchange his lsb. If Bh5, I go Be2. Of course, black has countergame...
moves.16... Rh2: Ouch! Ok, what is this R doing here?
moves.17. Nc5: This has two purposes: the first, conquer my outpost, and, second and more important, allow my Q to go to b3-a4 in case of Bh5. Because I am now aware Be2 doesn't work anymore.
moves.17... Rxb2: A mistake! If Rd-h8, black would have probably won the game, but this just helps me to get open column b to his K. Now, I can get rid of his lsb. Please, come in... ;-)
moves.18. Bd3: I threaten BxB, doubling and isolating his pawns.
moves.18... Bxd3 19. Qxd3: I have to be careful: if Nxd3, Qa3 and his pieces become unbearably active!
moves.19... g6 20. Rh1: ...Stopping any Rd-h8 ideas, and threatening Rh7, with pressure on f7.
moves.20... Rg2: This R is well installed on the second rank, but its purpose is limited! Now, this makes me free to pressure on the b column.
moves.21. Rb1: Threatening as a minimum a N fork on his Q and R. Na5 was the only way for black to escape his fate. I'd had a hard time. But he played the light...
moves.21... b6: ?? Incredible, I'm too lucky these days! "White plays a move and black resigns". Too easy.
moves.22. Qa6+: Some more points over the 1600 barrier. Sometimes is the opponent who blunders a game. I am aware I can't expect this to go on for too long... Thanks for reading!
